expanded_description: How do central banks manage the economy? What tools do they use to influence inflation, employment, and growth? Monetary policy—the actions of a central bank to manage the money supply and interest rates—is one of the most powerful forces in any economy. In the United States, the Federal Reserve (the Fed) conducts monetary policy to achieve its dual mandate: maximum employment and stable prices. When the economy is weak, the Fed lowers interest rates to stimulate borrowing and spending. When inflation threatens, it raises rates to cool things down. Understanding monetary policy—its goals, tools, and limitations—is essential for understanding how the economy is managed. In this section, we'll explore what monetary policy is, who conducts it, the tools they use, and how those tools affect the economy.

core_concept.principle: Monetary policy refers to the actions undertaken by a central bank to manage the money supply and interest rates to achieve macroeconomic policy goals. In the United States, the Federal Reserve conducts monetary policy with a dual mandate from Congress: to promote maximum employment and stable prices (the Fed interprets stable prices as a 2% inflation target over the long run). The Fed also aims for moderate long-term interest rates, which tend to follow from the first two goals. Monetary policy works through several channels. When the Fed wants to stimulate the economy (expansionary monetary policy), it lowers interest rates. Lower rates reduce the cost of borrowing for households and businesses, encouraging spending on consumption and investment. This increases aggregate demand, boosting output and employment. When the Fed wants to cool an overheating economy and fight inflation (contractionary monetary policy), it raises interest rates. Higher rates discourage borrowing and spending, reducing aggregate demand and easing inflationary pressure. The Fed has three main policy tools. (1) Open market operations: The Fed buys or sells government securities to influence the federal funds rate (the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans). Buying securities injects reserves into the banking system, lowering rates. Selling securities drains reserves, raising rates. (2) The discount rate: The interest rate the Fed charges banks for direct loans. Changing it influences banks' willingness to borrow reserves. (3) Reserve requirements: The fraction of deposits banks must hold as reserves. Changing requirements affects the money multiplier and banks' lending capacity. In practice, the Fed primarily uses open market operations and, since 2008, interest on reserves (IOR) to implement policy. In times of crisis, the Fed may use unconventional tools like quantitative easing (large-scale asset purchases) and forward guidance (communicating future policy intentions) to provide additional stimulus when short-term rates are already near zero.
core_concept.explanation: Imagine you're driving a car. Monetary policy is like the accelerator and brake. When the economy is sluggish (going up a hill), the Fed steps on the accelerator—lowering interest rates—to give it more power and keep it moving. When the economy is overheating and inflation is rising (going too fast down a hill), the Fed taps the brakes—raising interest rates—to slow it down to a safe speed. The Fed's target speed is around 2% inflation and maximum employment. The tools are like the pedals: open market operations are the main accelerator/brake; the discount rate and reserve requirements are like fine-tuning adjustments. And just as a driver needs to look ahead and anticipate hills and curves, the Fed must be forward-looking because monetary policy works with lags—it takes time for interest rate changes to affect the economy.

sections.introduction: Central banks are among the most powerful institutions in modern economies. Their decisions on interest rates ripple through financial markets, affect borrowing costs for households and businesses, influence exchange rates, and ultimately determine the path of inflation and employment. In this section, we'll explore the basics of monetary policy: what it is, who conducts it, the goals it pursues, and the tools it uses. Understanding these fundamentals is essential for analyzing how policymakers respond to economic conditions and how their actions affect the economy.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 4.2.2: Central banks use monetary policy to influence economic conditions.

key_concept.definition: Monetary policy is the process by which a central bank manages the supply of money and the cost of credit to achieve specific economic goals. The Federal Reserve, the central bank of the United States, conducts monetary policy under a dual mandate from Congress: to promote maximum employment and stable prices. The Fed also seeks moderate long-term interest rates, which tend to result from achieving the first two goals. The policy framework works through the following transmission mechanism. First, the Fed uses its tools to influence the federal funds rate—the interest rate banks charge each other for overnight loans. This rate affects other short-term interest rates (like bank prime rates) and, through expectations, long-term rates (like mortgage and corporate bond rates). Changes in interest rates affect borrowing costs for households and businesses. Lower rates encourage borrowing for consumption (homes, cars) and investment (new plants, equipment), increasing aggregate demand. Higher rates discourage borrowing, reducing aggregate demand. Changes in aggregate demand then affect output, employment, and inflation. When the economy is weak, the Fed lowers rates to stimulate demand (expansionary policy). When inflation threatens, the Fed raises rates to cool demand (contractionary policy). The Fed has three conventional policy tools. (1) Open market operations: The Fed buys or sells government securities on the open market. Buying securities injects reserves into the banking system, putting downward pressure on the federal funds rate. Selling securities drains reserves, putting upward pressure on the rate. Open market operations are the Fed's primary tool, conducted daily by the Trading Desk at the New York Fed. (2) The discount rate: The interest rate the Fed charges banks for direct loans from the discount window. Banks can borrow to meet reserve needs. A higher discount rate discourages borrowing; a lower rate encourages it. The discount rate also serves as a ceiling for the federal funds rate. (3) Reserve requirements: The fraction of deposits banks must hold as reserves. Changing requirements affects the money multiplier and banks' lending capacity. However, reserve requirements are rarely changed; the Fed set them to zero in 2020. Since 2008, the Fed has also used interest on reserves (IOR)—the rate paid on banks' reserve balances—as a key tool to help control the federal funds rate, especially in an environment of abundant reserves. In times of crisis, when conventional tools are insufficient (e.g., when short-term rates are near zero), the Fed may use unconventional tools: quantitative easing (large-scale purchases of longer-term securities to lower long-term rates) and forward guidance (communicating the likely future path of policy to influence expectations).
key_concept.context: Monetary policy has evolved significantly over time. In the 19th and early 20th centuries, central banks focused primarily on maintaining convertibility to gold. The Great Depression led to new thinking about the central bank's role in stabilizing the economy. The 1970s stagflation highlighted the importance of controlling inflation. The 2008 financial crisis and 2020 pandemic recession pushed central banks to develop new tools and frameworks. Today, monetary policy is a central focus of macroeconomic policy, with central banks in most countries operating independently to achieve price stability and support economic growth. In AP Macroeconomics, understanding monetary policy is essential for analyzing how policymakers respond to economic fluctuations and how their actions affect inflation, unemployment, and growth.

image.caption: Figure 4.2.3: The monetary policy transmission mechanism: Fed tools affect interest rates, which affect spending, which affects output and inflation.

classifications.value: Policy designed to stimulate the economy
classifications.behavior: Expansionary monetary policy aims to increase aggregate demand when the economy is operating below potential (negative output gap, high unemployment). The Fed lowers the target federal funds rate through open market purchases (buying securities, injecting reserves). Lower rates reduce borrowing costs, encouraging households to buy homes and cars and businesses to invest in new equipment and facilities. Lower rates also weaken the exchange rate (if other countries' rates don't fall as much), boosting net exports. The resulting increase in aggregate demand raises output and employment. However, if pushed too far, expansionary policy can overstimulate the economy, causing inflation to rise above target.

image.alt: Diagram showing Fed lowering rates, AD increasing, output rising, unemployment falling
image.caption: Figure 4.2.4: Expansionary monetary policy lowers interest rates, boosting aggregate demand, output, and employment.

examples.explanation: The Fed cut the federal funds rate from 5.25% to near zero between 2007 and 2008. It also used unconventional tools like quantitative easing to provide additional stimulus. This expansionary policy helped end the Great Recession and support recovery.

The Fed cut rates to zero in March 2020, restarted quantitative easing, and provided forward guidance that rates would stay low for an extended period. This supported the economy through the pandemic shutdowns.

classifications.value: Policy designed to slow the economy
classifications.behavior: Contractionary monetary policy aims to decrease aggregate demand when the economy is operating above potential (positive output gap, rising inflation). The Fed raises the target federal funds rate through open market sales (selling securities, draining reserves). Higher rates increase borrowing costs, discouraging households from buying homes and cars and businesses from investing. Higher rates may also strengthen the exchange rate, reducing net exports. The resulting decrease in aggregate demand reduces inflationary pressure. However, contractionary policy can slow the economy too much, potentially causing a recession if overdone. The challenge is to apply just enough restraint to control inflation without causing unnecessary unemployment.

image.alt: Diagram showing Fed raising rates, AD decreasing, output falling, inflation falling
image.caption: Figure 4.2.5: Contractionary monetary policy raises interest rates, reducing aggregate demand and inflationary pressure.

examples.explanation: Fed Chair Paul Volcker raised the federal funds rate to nearly 20% to break double-digit inflation. This caused a severe recession but successfully reduced inflation from over 13% to around 3%.
As inflation surged to 40-year highs, the Fed raised rates from near zero to over 5% between 2022 and 2023—the fastest tightening cycle since the 1980s—to bring inflation back toward its 2% target.

characteristics: Conducted daily by New York Fed
classifications.behavior: Open market operations are the Fed's most important and frequently used tool. When the Fed wants to lower interest rates (expansionary policy), it buys government securities from banks and other financial institutions. The Fed pays by crediting the sellers' reserve accounts, increasing the supply of reserves in the banking system. With more reserves available, the federal funds rate falls. When the Fed wants to raise rates (contractionary policy), it sells securities, debiting reserve accounts, decreasing the supply of reserves, and pushing the federal funds rate up. The Trading Desk at the New York Fed conducts these operations almost daily, aiming to keep the effective federal funds rate close to the FOMC's target. Operations can be outright purchases/sales (permanent) or repurchase agreements/reverse repos (temporary).

image.alt: Diagram showing Fed buying securities (reserves increase, rates down) and selling securities (reserves decrease, rates up)
image.caption: Figure 4.2.6: Open market operations: buying securities injects reserves and lowers rates; selling drains reserves and raises rates.

examples.explanation: The New York Fed conducts open market operations each day to fine-tune the federal funds rate, offsetting temporary fluctuations in reserves from factors like Treasury payments or changes in currency demand.
During crises, the Fed conducts large-scale open market purchases (QE) to lower long-term rates and provide stimulus when short-term rates are already near zero.

classifications.value: Interest rate on Fed loans to banks
classifications.behavior: The discount rate is the interest rate the Fed charges commercial banks for loans obtained through the discount window. Banks can borrow to meet reserve requirements, address temporary liquidity needs, or in emergencies. The discount rate is typically set above the federal funds target, creating a ceiling—banks won't pay more in the federal funds market than they can borrow from the Fed. Changing the discount rate affects banks' willingness to borrow reserves and can signal the Fed's policy intentions. A higher discount rate discourages borrowing; a lower rate encourages it. However, banks have historically been reluctant to use the discount window due to stigma (fear that borrowing signals weakness).

image.alt: Diagram showing bank borrowing from Fed at discount rate, with discount rate as ceiling
image.caption: Figure 4.2.7: The discount rate is the interest rate on Fed loans to banks. It acts as a ceiling for the federal funds rate.

examples.explanation: The discount rate is set above the federal funds target. Banks rarely borrow from the discount window, preferring to borrow in the federal funds market at lower rates.
During the 2008 crisis, the Fed reduced the spread between the discount rate and the federal funds target and expanded discount window lending to provide liquidity to the banking system.

principles.principle: Monetary Policy Affects the Economy Through Interest Rates
principles.statement: Changes in the federal funds rate ripple through the entire interest rate structure. When the Fed lowers the federal funds rate, other short-term rates (like bank prime rates, credit card rates, and short-term business loans) typically fall. Long-term rates (mortgages, corporate bonds) are influenced by expectations of future short-term rates, so they also tend to fall when the Fed signals that rates will stay low. Lower rates reduce the cost of borrowing, encouraging households to spend more on homes, cars, and other durable goods, and encouraging businesses to invest in new plants, equipment, and inventory. This increased spending boosts aggregate demand, raising output and employment. Conversely, higher rates discourage borrowing and spending, reducing aggregate demand and easing inflationary pressure. This transmission mechanism is why interest rates are the primary focus of monetary policy.
principles.application: When analyzing the effects of monetary policy, trace the path from the Fed's action to interest rates to spending. A rate cut should eventually boost interest-sensitive sectors like housing and business investment. A rate hike should cool those sectors. The lags involved mean policy effects take time—often 12-18 months to fully materialize.
principles.example: When the Fed cut rates to zero in 2020, mortgage rates fell to record lows. This sparked a housing boom, with existing home sales surging and home prices rising sharply. Business investment in equipment also increased as borrowing costs fell. This spending helped fuel the rapid recovery from the pandemic recession.

image.alt: Flow diagram: Fed rate change → other rates → borrowing costs → spending → output
image.caption: Figure 4.2.8: Monetary policy works through interest rates. Lower rates encourage spending; higher rates discourage it.

principles.principle: Monetary Policy Operates with Long and Variable Lags
principles.statement: Monetary policy does not affect the economy instantly. There are two types of lags. Inside lags: The time between recognizing an economic problem and taking action. The Fed can act quickly—the FOMC meets eight times per year and can hold emergency meetings—so inside lags are relatively short. Outside lags: The time between taking action and the action affecting the economy. These are long and variable—typically 12 to 18 months for the full effects of an interest rate change to be felt. Interest rate changes take time to affect borrowing decisions, and spending changes take time to work through the economy. These long lags make monetary policy difficult: the Fed must be forward-looking, acting based on where the economy is expected to be in one to two years, not where it is today.
principles.application: When evaluating Fed decisions, consider that they are based on forecasts, not current conditions. The Fed may raise rates even if inflation is currently low if it expects inflation to rise in the future. It may cut rates even if the economy is currently growing if it expects a slowdown ahead. This forward-looking stance is necessary because of lags.
principles.example: In 2021, the Fed maintained low rates even as inflation began rising, believing inflation would be transitory. When inflation proved persistent, the Fed had to raise rates rapidly in 2022-23. Critics argued the Fed waited too long, but the decision reflected uncertainty about whether inflation would persist and the lagged effects of policy.

image.alt: Timeline showing recognition lag, action lag, and impact lag
image.caption: Figure 4.2.9: Monetary policy operates with long and variable lags—especially the outside lag between action and effect.

principles.principle: The Fed Has a Dual Mandate
principles.statement: The Fed's monetary policy goals are set by Congress: maximum employment, stable prices, and moderate long-term interest rates. This is often called the 'dual mandate' (though it has three parts). Maximum employment means the highest level of employment the economy can sustain without inflationary pressure—essentially the natural rate of unemployment. Stable prices means low, stable inflation—the Fed has set a 2% inflation target as its interpretation of price stability. Moderate long-term interest rates follow from the first two—when the economy is at full employment with stable prices, long-term rates tend to be moderate. The dual mandate means the Fed must balance both goals. When inflation is low and unemployment high, it focuses on stimulating employment. When inflation rises above target, it focuses on price stability. Sometimes the goals conflict, requiring judgment and trade-offs.
principles.application: When analyzing Fed actions, consider how they balance the dual mandate. In a recession, the Fed focuses on maximum employment, cutting rates to stimulate the economy. When inflation rises, it focuses on price stability, raising rates to cool the economy. The Fed's statements often explain how it sees the balance.
principles.example: In 2020, with unemployment spiking, the Fed focused on maximum employment, cutting rates to zero and providing massive stimulus. In 2022-23, as inflation surged, the Fed shifted focus to price stability, raising rates aggressively. Both actions reflect the dual mandate, with the priority shifting as conditions changed.

image.alt: Balance scale with maximum employment on one side, stable prices on the other, Fed in middle
image.caption: Figure 4.2.10: The Fed's dual mandate requires balancing maximum employment and stable prices.

principles.principle: At the Zero Lower Bound, Unconventional Tools Become Necessary
principles.statement: When the federal funds rate is near zero, the Fed cannot provide additional stimulus by cutting rates further. This is the zero lower bound. At this point, conventional monetary policy is exhausted, and the Fed must use unconventional tools. Quantitative easing (QE)—large-scale purchases of longer-term securities (Treasuries and mortgage-backed securities)—lowers long-term interest rates and provides additional stimulus. Forward guidance—communicating the likely future path of policy—shapes expectations, lowering rates today even without immediate action. The Fed may also use negative interest rates (charging banks for holding reserves) in some countries, though the Fed has been reluctant to do so. These tools were used extensively after 2008 and again in 2020. They are now part of the standard toolkit, though their effectiveness and potential side effects are debated.
principles.application: When rates are near zero, look for unconventional policy. QE announcements affect long-term bond yields. Forward guidance statements affect expectations. These tools show that monetary policy can still provide stimulus even when short-term rates can't go lower.
principles.example: In March 2020, with rates already at zero, the Fed announced unlimited QE, buying Treasuries and mortgage-backed securities. It also provided forward guidance that rates would stay low until employment recovered. Long-term rates fell, supporting the recovery. The Fed also established emergency lending facilities to support specific markets.

image.alt: Graph showing fed funds rate at zero, with QE and forward guidance arrows providing additional stimulus
image.caption: Figure 4.2.11: At the zero lower bound, the Fed uses unconventional tools: quantitative easing and forward guidance.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Monetary Policy Type

image.caption: Figure 4.2.12: Identify whether each scenario calls for expansionary or contractionary policy.

worked_examples.problem: For each scenario, determine whether the Fed should use expansionary or contractionary monetary policy. a) Real GDP is falling, unemployment is rising, and inflation is low. b) Inflation is 5% (above the 2% target) and unemployment is at the natural rate. c) The economy is growing strongly, unemployment is below the natural rate, and inflation is starting to rise. d) The economy is in a deep recession with high unemployment and very low inflation. e) An oil price shock has caused both inflation to rise and output to fall (stagflation).

step_by_step.explanation: Falling GDP and rising unemployment indicate a recession or slowdown. Inflation is low, so no immediate inflation concern. The Fed should use expansionary policy to stimulate demand and reduce unemployment.

Inflation is well above target, even though unemployment is at the natural rate. The economy is overheating. The Fed should use contractionary policy to reduce aggregate demand and bring inflation back to target.
Strong growth, unemployment below natural rate, and rising inflation all signal an overheating economy. The Fed should use contractionary policy to prevent inflation from rising further.
Deep recession with high unemployment and very low inflation clearly calls for expansionary policy to stimulate demand and reduce unemployment.

Stagflation presents a dilemma: contractionary policy would fight inflation but worsen unemployment; expansionary policy would fight unemployment but worsen inflation. The Fed must weigh both goals and may focus on inflation if it's high and persistent, or on unemployment if the shock is temporary. There's no single right answer—it depends on the Fed's judgment.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Expansionary. b) Contractionary. c) Contractionary. d) Expansionary. e) Dilemma—depends on circumstances.
worked_examples.concept_applied: The choice between expansionary and contractionary policy depends on whether the economy is below or above potential, and on the relative threats of unemployment and inflation.

worked_examples.title: The Monetary Policy Transmission Mechanism

image.alt: Flowchart with blank boxes to fill in
image.caption: Figure 4.2.13: Trace the transmission mechanism from Fed action to final economic effects.

worked_examples.problem: The Fed decides to lower the federal funds rate target by 0.5 percentage points. Trace the transmission mechanism step by step, explaining what happens at each stage and why. Start with the Fed's open market operation and end with the effects on output and inflation. Identify the key assumptions and potential reasons the transmission might be weaker than expected.

step_by_step.explanation: To lower the federal funds rate, the New York Fed buys government securities from banks. It pays by crediting banks' reserve accounts, increasing the supply of reserves in the banking system.
With more reserves available, banks are willing to lend reserves to each other at lower rates. The federal funds rate declines toward the Fed's new target.
The federal funds rate influences other short-term rates—bank prime rate, short-term business loans, credit card rates, etc. These rates typically move in the same direction as the fed funds rate.

Long-term rates (mortgages, corporate bonds) are influenced by expectations of future short-term rates. If the Fed signals rates will stay low, long-term rates may also fall. (This is less certain and depends on market expectations.)

Lower rates reduce borrowing costs. Households are more likely to buy homes, cars, and other durable goods. Businesses are more likely to invest in new equipment, facilities, and inventory. Lower rates may also weaken the dollar, boosting net exports.
The increase in consumption, investment, and net exports shifts the aggregate demand curve to the right.
Higher aggregate demand leads firms to increase production and hire more workers. Real GDP rises, unemployment falls.
As the economy approaches potential GDP, tighter resource markets put upward pressure on wages and prices, increasing inflation. The magnitude depends on how close the economy is to potential.
Transmission may be weaker if: banks don't pass on rate cuts to borrowers, households and businesses are too pessimistic to borrow, long-term rates don't fall, or the economy is in a liquidity trap.

worked_examples.final_answer: Open market purchase → reserves increase → fed funds rate falls → other rates fall → borrowing and spending increase → AD increases → output and employment rise → inflation may rise.
worked_examples.concept_applied: The transmission mechanism shows how Fed actions affect the economy through interest rates and spending. Many steps must work for policy to be effective.

worked_examples.title: Policy at the Zero Lower Bound

image.alt: Graph showing fed funds rate at zero, economy in recession
image.caption: Figure 4.2.14: When the fed funds rate is already zero, conventional policy is exhausted.

worked_examples.problem: The economy is in a severe recession. The Fed has already cut the federal funds rate to zero, but the economy remains weak with high unemployment and very low inflation. a) Why can't the Fed simply cut rates further? b) What unconventional tools does the Fed have available? c) How does quantitative easing work to stimulate the economy? d) How does forward guidance work? e) What are the potential risks of using these unconventional tools?

step_by_step.explanation: Nominal interest rates cannot fall much below zero because people would simply hold cash rather than lend at negative rates. Once the fed funds rate is at zero, conventional policy (cutting the target rate) is exhausted. This is the zero lower bound.

The Fed's unconventional tools include: quantitative easing (large-scale asset purchases), forward guidance (communicating future policy intentions), negative interest rates (charging on reserves—used in some countries but not the U.S.), and emergency lending facilities.

QE involves the Fed buying large quantities of longer-term securities (Treasuries, mortgage-backed securities). This increases demand for these securities, raising their prices and lowering their yields (long-term interest rates). Lower long-term rates encourage borrowing for mortgages, business investment, etc. QE also signals that the Fed will keep rates low for an extended period.

Forward guidance means the Fed communicates its likely future policy path. For example, it might say it expects to keep rates near zero until unemployment falls below a certain level or inflation reaches target. This shapes expectations, lowering long-term rates today and encouraging spending even without immediate Fed action.

Risks include: inflation if QE is excessive; asset bubbles as low rates drive up prices of stocks and real estate; distortions in financial markets; difficulty exiting (selling bonds without disrupting markets); potential loss of confidence in the Fed; and distributional effects (benefiting asset holders more than workers).

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Zero lower bound prevents negative rates. b) QE, forward guidance, negative rates, emergency lending. c) QE lowers long-term rates. d) Forward guidance shapes expectations. e) Inflation, asset bubbles, exit challenges.
worked_examples.concept_applied: At the zero lower bound, conventional policy is exhausted. The Fed must use unconventional tools to provide additional stimulus.

process_flow.description: Based on economic conditions and forecasts, the FOMC decides whether to ease, tighten, or maintain policy. It sets a target for the federal funds rate.
process_flow.mechanism: The FOMC meets eight times per year, reviewing data on growth, employment, inflation, and financial conditions. It issues a statement announcing its decision and forward guidance.

image.caption: Figure 4.2.15: Step 1 - FOMC sets the target federal funds rate based on economic conditions.

process_flow.process: New York Fed Conducts Open Market Operations
process_flow.description: The Trading Desk at the New York Fed conducts open market operations to achieve the FOMC's target.
process_flow.mechanism: To lower rates, the Desk buys government securities, injecting reserves. To raise rates, it sells securities, draining reserves. Operations are conducted daily to keep the effective fed funds rate at target.
process_flow.result: Federal funds rate moves to target.

image.alt: New York Fed trading desk with screens
image.caption: Figure 4.2.16: Step 2 - New York Fed conducts open market operations to implement FOMC decisions.

process_flow.description: Changes in the federal funds rate influence other short-term rates and, through expectations, long-term rates.
process_flow.mechanism: Bank prime rates, credit card rates, and short-term business loans typically move with the fed funds rate. Mortgage rates and corporate bond yields are influenced by expectations of future short-term rates.
process_flow.result: Borrowing costs change for households and businesses.

image.alt: Arrows from fed funds rate to mortgage rates, car loan rates, business loan rates
image.caption: Figure 4.2.17: Step 3 - Changes in the fed funds rate affect other interest rates throughout the economy.

process_flow.description: Households and businesses adjust their spending based on new borrowing costs.
process_flow.mechanism: Lower rates encourage borrowing for homes, cars, and investment. Higher rates discourage borrowing. Changes in spending affect aggregate demand.

image.alt: House buying car, business building factory, with interest rate arrows
image.caption: Figure 4.2.18: Step 4 - Changes in interest rates affect household and business spending decisions.

process_flow.description: Changes in aggregate demand affect real GDP, employment, and eventually inflation.
process_flow.mechanism: Increased demand leads firms to produce more and hire more, raising output and employment. As the economy approaches potential, inflation rises. Decreased demand has opposite effects.

image.caption: Figure 4.2.19: Step 5 - Changes in spending affect output, employment, and ultimately inflation.
